clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of IgA Levels in the Bronchoalveolar Lavage Fluid of Patients With and Without Antibiotic Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of IgA Levels in the Bronchoalveolar Lavage Fluid of Patients With and Without Antibiotic Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: Investigators hypothesize that Immunoglobine (Ig) production is influenced by the microbiota of the gut. Investigators will compare microbiota-dependent Ig production in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of patients with and without antibiotic therapy in order to detect significant differences.

primary_outcome.measure: IgA levels in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid

secondary_outcome.measure: number of detected bacterial, viral, and fungal infections per patient
secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 2 months

arm_group.description: Patients with antibiotic therapy for 2 weeks.
Patients without any antibiotic therapy in the last 3 months.

intervention.description: administration of any antibiotic substance(s) over the course of 2 weeks

biospec_descr.textblock: bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of patients with and without antibiotic therapy.

study_pop.textblock: Consecutive inclusion of eligible patients admitted to the ICU.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- endotracheal intubation
- antibiotic therapy for 2 weeks OR no antibiotic therapy
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnancy
- immunodeficiency

reference.citation: Hoogkamp-Korstanje JA, de Koning J, Heesemann J, Festen JJ, Houtman PM, van Oyen PL. Influence of antibiotics on IgA and IgG response and persistence of Yersinia enterocolitica in patients with Yersinia-associated spondylarthropathy. Infection. 1992 Mar-Apr;20(2):53-7.
